{{Dablink|Not to be confused with the original Harimau Muda team, [[Harimau Muda]] and the Harimau Muda "B" team, [[Harimau Muda B]]}} {{Infobox National football team | Name = Malaysia U-22 | Badge = Harimau Muda A Logo.png | FIFA Trigramme = MAS | Nickname = Young Tigers | Association = [[Football Association of Malaysia]]| Coach = {{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Ong Kim Swee]] | Assistant Coach = | Captain = [[Mohd Muslim Ahmad]] | Most caps = | Top scorer = | | pattern_la1=_malaysia10h|pattern_b1=_MAS10h|pattern_ra1=_malaysia10h|pattern_sh1=_yellowsides|pattern_so1=_mal10h | leftarm1=000000|body1=FFD700|rightarm1=000000|shorts1=000000|socks1=FFD700 | pattern_la2=_malaysia10a|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=_malaysia10a|pattern_sh2=_usa10h|pattern_so2=_caen1011h | leftarm2=0033FF|body2=0033FF|rightarm2=0033FF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=0033FF |First game = {{flagicon|Malaya}} [[Malaysia national football team|Malaya]] 12â0 {{flagicon|Ceylon|1951}} [[Sri Lanka national football team|Ceylon]]
([[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]]; April 18, 1959)| Largest win = {{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] 12â0 {{flagicon|Brunei}} [[Brunei national football team|Brunei]]
([[Palembang]], [[Indonesia]]; August 13, 2005)| Largest loss = {{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] 0â7 {{flagicon|Iraq|1963}} [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]]
([[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]]; October 13, 1978)| World cup apps = |1 World cup first = |1997 World cup best = |Round 1 Regional name = |AFC Youth Championship Regional cup apps = | Regional cup first = |1959 Regional cup best = |Runners-up }} '''Harimau Muda A''', or '''Malaysia national under-22 football team''' also known as '''Malaysia U-22''', represents [[Malaysia]] in international [[football (soccer)|football]] competitions such as [[AFC Youth Championship]], [[Champions Youth Cup]] and as well as any other under-22 international football tournaments. It is controlled by the [[Football Association of Malaysia]]. The team is considered to be the feeder team for the [[Malaysia national under-23 football team|Malaysia U-23]] and senior national football teams. It is for players aged 21 and less until the aged of 19 while [[Harimau Muda B]] is in charged of the under-19 players. Harimau Muda A will participate in the [[2012 S. League]] replacing [[Young Lions (Singapore football team)|Young Lions]]. The team is aimed at developing Malaysian youth players and will not recruit any foreign nationals in its squad. The name "Harimau Muda" means "Young Tigers" in [[English language|English]]. ==Formation== {{details|Harimau Muda}} On October 19, 2007 FAM decided to include Malaysia U-21 as one of the team in [[2007â08 Premier League Malaysia]] and will be known as ''Harimau Muda'' (Young Tigers).[http://thestar.com.my/sports/story.asp?file=/2007/10/20/sports/19229346 Brunei DPMM get to play in FA Cup, not Malaysia Cup] Due to international duties, the Malaysia national U-21 team were needed to participate in the [[2010 AFC U-19 Championship qualification]]. In local competition, they participated in the [[2009 Premier League Malaysia|Premier League]] and the [[Malaysia FA Cup 2009|FA Cup]]. The Harimau Muda were split in to 2 teams on July 2009, Harimau Muda A and [[Harimau Muda B]]. The Harimau Muda B were sent to [[Zibo]], [[People's Republic of China|China]] to participate in the [[2010 AFC U-19 Championship qualification]] and Harimau Muda A was to participate in the Premier League and FA Cup. During the 2010 season, Harimau Muda A went to a training camp in [[ZlatÃ© Moravce]], [[Slovakia]] for 8 months while Harimau Muda B participated in the [[2010 Malaysia Premier League]]. After the stint in Slovakia, Harimau Muda A joined the [[2011 Super League Malaysia]] replacing [[PLUS FC|KL PLUS FC]] and Harimau Muda B continued to play in the [[2011 Malaysia Premier League|Malaysia Premier League]]. Harimau Muda A finished 5th while Harimau Muda B played their worst season being in the bottom 3. However, they managed to avoid relegation and will continue to play in the [[Malaysia Premier League]]. For the 2012 season, Harimau Muda A swapped places with the [[Young Lions (Singapore football team)|Young Lions]] of [[Football Association of Singapore|Singapore]], which is made up of the Singapore's national under-23 team. [[Young Lions (Singapore football team)|Young Lions]] will replace Harimau Muda A in the [[2012 Malaysia Super League|Super League]] while the Harimau Muda A will replace the [[Young Lions (Singapore football team)|Young Lions]] in the [[S. League]].{{cite web|publisher=BERNAMA|title=Harimau Muda to play in S-League, Young Lions In Malaysia's Super League|url=http://www.bernama.com.my/bernama/v5/newsgeneral.php?id=600787|language=English|accessdate=2011-06-12}} Harimau Muda B will continue to participate in the [[Malaysia Premier League]]. ==Competition records== {| class="wikitable float-right" |- !
